I want to thank all AFN 2021 attendees for their continued leadership on behalf of Alaska Natives. I'm proud to serve as your partner in the House. As always, if you‚Äôd like to share your views on legislation before Congress, don't hesitate to contact me: https://donyoung.house.gov/contact/

My amendment would help to end the disproportionately high levels of violence against Indigenous women by ensuring Alaska Native villages have jurisdiction for the Alaska tribal jurisdiction pilot program.

I‚Äôll continue working hard this Congress to fight the MMIWG crisis. Earlier this year, I helped the House reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act (#VAWA). I am pleased that this bill retains my amendment to help combat violence directed at Native American women.

This bill, now law, requires the establishment of a commission that includes Tribal, state, & local officials, in addition to Tribal judges & healthcare providers to help law enforcement better respond to the unique needs of Indigenous communities as they investigate MMIWG cases.
Last year, we also passed the Not Invisible Act, which I was proud to help introduce alongside my friend, then-Congresswoman Deb Haaland.
Too many families do not feel comfortable reporting missing loved ones because of a lack of culturally appropriate law enforcement training. Savanna's Act will help address this.

Additionally, it requires the DOJ to offer culturally specific training for law enforcement to help them better understand what their role is in MMIWG cases, and to help them tailor responses to Alaska Native and Native American communities.

Because of its passage, the Department of Justice (DOJ) is now required to create a task force to bring law enforcement, first responders, and Indigenous communities together to get on the same page to respond to a missing person case.
Last Congress, I helped lead House passage of Savanna's Act and the Not Invisible Act, which were signed into law. Savannah's Act represents a significant step in the right direction.
